cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are Intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid fall fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent, on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

R.M.S "Oroya" will leave Suez about April 6.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Ophir" will leave Port Said March 26
R.M.S. “Orient" will leave Port Said April 9
Egyptian Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% of the above fares.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage be made within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20% if return voyage be made within 6 months of arrival.

S.S. Herefordshire 7,182 tons, will leave Suez about March 29th.
S.S. Shropshire 6,755 tons, will leave Suez about April 12th.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON.
S.S. Derbyshire 6,336 tons, will leave Port Said about March 18th.
S.S. Worcestershire 7,160 tons, will leave Port Said about April 1st.

Agents in Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. For all particulars apply to Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS PORT SAID PORT TEWFIK (Suez).

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: GRAND HOTEL KHARTOUM, SUDAN
div.p: SUDAN.
First Class. Open all the year round.
THOROUGHLY RENOVATED AND IMPROVED.

Standing in a magnificent position in its own extensive grounds on the banks of the Blue Nile. Perfect climate, no mosquitoes, moder comfort, very homely. Concerts twice a week on the verandah of the Hotel.
ENTIRELY NEW MANAGEMENT.
For accommodation please write or wire beforehand to Manager
G. OTTO BOCK, Manager.
Lake Holland House, New York.

15 Minutes by Carriage or "Palais tram from Sidi Gaber Station.
The most charming Sea-side Residence in Egypt.
First Class Family Hotel with Every Modern Comfort.
Unique Situation on the Beach.

G. RUNCKEWITZ, Proprietor.

div.head: The George Nungovich Hotels
div.p: Grand Hotel, Helouan.- Finest and most luxurious Hotel near Cairo. Patronized by Royalty. Moderate charges. Special terms for residents.

Hotel des Bains.- Most comfortable hotel, opposite the Baths. Pension from P.T. 40. Attached to the above hotels and specially reserved for their clients are the Golf Links (18 holes) with English Professional. Own Golf House in the dessert.
Sulphur Bath Establishment.- Sulphur water stronger than any in Europe. Eight European Masseurs and Masseuses. Every modern improvement.

div.head: FORCE APRÈS MALADIE
div.p: De même que la plus petite graine peut donner naissance à un très grand arbre, le moindre rhume, la toux la plus légère peuvent engendrer une longue et dangereuse maladie s'ils ne sont, en temps opportun, enrayés à l'aide de l'Emulsion Scott.

Toutes affections de la gorge et la poitrine, de quelque nature et si opiniâtres, si anciennes qu'elles soient, cèdent rapidement à l'efficacité de
qui vous refait des poumons capables de résister à toute intempéries ou autres influences malfaisantes.
Quand les fièvres ou une longue et douloureuse maladie ont réduit le corps à un inquiétant état de faiblesse et d'amaigrissement, un reconstituant qui vous remettra promptement est nécessaire.
l'EMULSION SCOTT

est le meilleur fortifiant du monde: ell na pas d..... Ell stimule l'appétit et améliore promptement la digestion. Elle fait des muscles et enrichit le sang, ell .... vitalité et donne à l'organism le pouvoir de résister à la maladie. L'Emulsion Scott est autant un alanent .... remède, car ell fournit au corps affaibli ce dont il a besoin pour reprendre muscles et forces ; ses nombres..... faisant résultats sont, en vérité, surprenants. Il y a reclle...ment grand danger à perdre embonpoint et pois à l'organism, bientôt débilité, deviendrait une proie facile pour la maladie.
L'EMULSION SCOTT

contient le principe fortifiant de tous aliments ; elle arrête le déperissement et reconstitutue une chair saine. Le flaton en est toujour présenté dans une enveloppe de papier couleur saumon avec, dessus, cette gravure.
En vente chez tous Pharmaciens et Droguistes.
Marque de Fabrique.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
ADVERTISEMENTS and SUBSCRIPTIONS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C.
Cairo Offices.-No. 1 Sharia Vervudachi, (opposite the Agricultural Bank.)
THE “EGYPTIAN GAZETTE” IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.)

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
Monday, March 19, 1906.

div.head: S.P.C.A
div.p: The eleventh annual report of the Cairo branch of the S.P.C.A. contains muoh interesting information for the friends of animals and fall statistical tables which show the excellent work done during the past year both by the Cairo branch and by the affiliated branches in the provinces. The increased receipts show that the society is doing well from a financial point of view, the convictions for various forms of ornelty show & gratifying decrease, and the infirmary has been thoroughly repaired and rearra" ged. All these facts are in the highest degree satisfactory, but there are two points in the report that are not altogether pleasant reading for the humane: we refer to the apparent reluctance of the tourist to assist the society and to the growing practice of underpaying cab-drivers. Mr. Rambold, who has done so much for the society daring the last few years, writes on the latter subject with most commendable frankness. After pointing out that the condition of the cab-borses in Cairo during the past summer and autumn has been worse than at any time döring. recent years owing to the unusually high price of forage and the low tariff, he shows that owners of cab-horses will appropriate the same margin of profit as they have done in the days of cheap forage. The price of tibn and coro increases bat only the same amount is spent on feeding the horses.

Bat what aggravates the situation is the habit of systematically underpaying the cabdrivers, on which the Hon. Secretary of the Cairo branch of the S.P.C.A. bas much to say. The remarks which follow perhaps seem to constitute rather too severe an indictment of certain Earopeans of the higher class, bat we have good reason to know that they are not in the slightest degree exaggerated. Mr. Rambold says : "It is to be regretted that the practice of paying even less than the fare is occasionally followed by Englishmen and other Europeang of the higher class, who might be expected to know better. The argument that when the cabdriver is overpaid he will reserve the excess fare for himself, and not devote it to giving his animals more to eat, may possibly hold good in some cases ; bat, by slightly overpaying a cab driver, he is "given the opportunity of improving the condition of his ani: mals. If he is, ander-paid, he is deprived of all chance of doing so, unless he is willing to starve himself. The society have been unable to do more than arrest the worst cases and treat them at the Infirmary. Ao argument which, strange as it may seem, has been advanced in defence of paying the cab-driver less than his proper fare is' that, although the tariff is indicated on a plate in every cab, it has no legal sanction. This argument is as erroneous as it is unworthy. The cab-tariff in Csiro is enacted by the Governor of Cairo and approved by the Mixed Courts. It is, therefore, binding on foreigners, and, in the event of their paying less than the legal fare, the cabdrivers would have ground for an action in the Mixed Courts. It need scarcely be remarked that & recourse to this remedy is entirely beyond the means of the majority of drivers, who must be content to see themselves defrauded of their proper fare."

As for tourist donations, we feel that it is hopeless to expect much from these birds of passage. A few years ago, when beasts covered with wounds and sores horrified the sensitive nerves of the visitor to Egypt, donations were frequent enough. Nowadays the tourist realises that the neighbourhood of Shepbeard's and the Savoy Hotel is free from soola sights and is quite satisfied. The fact that brutalities, the sight of which would disgust and sicken bim, are too frequent in the villages and country towns of Egypt, does not intrude upon his serenely optimistic assumption that the S.P.C.A. has no further need of his help.

. Clemenceau bas arrived bere. He addressed the strikers and said that he respecter their right to strike and would send no troops as long as they remained orderly, Owing to the danger of the decomposing bodies in the Courrières minor, it is expected that the authorities will decide to wall op.the galleries containing the victims, converting them into a vast necropolis. (Reuters)
The strikers pow number 82,0 o. M. Clenenceaa, Minister of the Interior, has visited the coalfields, and recommended calm. (H.)
The Courrières minors and masters' representatives have assembled here. The masters have conceded imoreases of wages which the men will consider (Reuters)

The delegates of the strikers at Pau.de Calais and the representatives of the mining comps pies met at the Ministry of Pablio Worke. The companies agree to an increase of 10 per conta The delegates will consult the strikers. (H.)

div.head: ALGECIRAS CONFERENCE.
COMPLETE STANDSTILL.
div.p: The Conference is at a complete standstill. The Swiss authorities are greatly annoyed at the Austro-German proposal to appoint a Swiss inspector without consulting the Federation. (Reuters)

div.head: CHINESE LABOUR.
A CONTROVERSY.
div.p: Mr. Winston Churchill, writing to a correspondent, a accuses Mr. Chamberlain of causing & depreciation in Kaffir securities by lugubrious and pessimistic orations.
Mr. Winston Churchill's speech in the House of Commons, and especially his threat of veto, bus aroused indignation in South Africa. (Reuters)

Mr. Chamberlain, in a letter to the Times," in reply to Mr. Winston Churchill (mentioned on the 16th instant), accuses the Government of inconsistency regarding the Chinese and declares that any attempt to veto the Transvaal Government's decision thereanent would probably lead to a serious conflict. (R.)

div.head: EDUCATION BILL.
NON-CONFORMISTS ALARMED.
div.p: The Non-conformists are alarmed by the rumours that the Government contemplate making concessions to Catholics in their new Education Bill, and threaten to renew the agitation in a most vigorous manner if this be true. (Reuters)

div.head: TURKEY AND PERSIA.
div.p: The British and Russian Embassies ara lending their good offices to secure an equitable settlement between Turkey and Persia. (R.)

div.head: BULGARIAN BANDS AGAIN.
div.p: Bulgarian bands are commencing their crimes of depredation again. They have set fire to a Greek village and killed several people. (Havas)

div.head: TERRIBLE EARTHQUAKE IN JAPAN
div.p: A terrible earthquake has taken place at Kagi. Several hundred buildings have been destroyed and many hundreds of persons have been killed or injured. (Reuter)

div.head: FLOODS IN BRAZIL.
div.p: Over 50 men have been killed and many injured owing to landslides and foods in Brazil. (Reuter)

div.head: RUSSIA AND JAPAN.
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, March 17. The report is denied that the Tsar is sending a Grand Duke to Japan. (Reuter)

div.head: SEVASTOPOL MUTINY.
div.p: The sentence on Lieutensnt Schmidt connected with the Sevastopol mutiny, has been commuted to being shot instead of being hanged. (Reuter)

div.head: ST. PATRICK'S DAY.
div.p: St. Patrick's Day was celebrated with the customary enthusiasm, and by concerts and parades of the Irish regiments. Shamrock was universalily worn in London. (Reuter)

div.head: CENSUS OF GERMAN EMPIRE.
div.p: The census of the German Empire shows a population of 60,605,183 (Reuter)

div.head: INTERNATIONAL FOOTBALL.
div.p: Association. Scotland beat Ireland by one to nil.
Rugby. England beat Scotland by 9 to 8. (Reuter)

div.head: OUR SPECIAL CABLES.
ALGECIRAS CONFERENCE.
INTERNATIONAL GUARANTEE DISCUSSED.
(Gazette' Special Service)
div.p: The "Echo de Paris” correspondent at Algeciras declares that the question of an international guarantee is at present being discussed in Paris, London, and Berlin by various members of the diplomatic corps. It is stated that a proposition has been forwarded by Italy in this connection. In the event of Germany acqnis-cing in this suggestion the Roccors of the conference is assured, otherwise failure is inevitable.

It has been an open secret for some time that Germany has been actively at work in the direction of obtaining from Turkey the concession of a port which could be turned into a naval station and coaling station. The Copatantinople correspondent of 'Le Petit Parisien" writes that Germany has made choice of the island of Thasos, in the extreme north of the Ægean Sea. The island was given to the Khedive Ismail Pasha, and the present Khedive is now its owner. Although the Khedive has worked the greater sart of the land and forests, he has granted certain concessions for exploiting the natural wealth of Thasos. The most important of these concassiops is one which we obtained some years ago by a syndicate of German Jews for the purpose of cutting down the timber. This syndicate was supported well by the German Government, and thanks to soch support from home it was able last year to obtain the right of working the mineral wealth of Thasos. The German Ambassador at the Porte bas demanded from Turkey the cagion of a harbour on Thasos in the interests of Germany's growing trade, and with a view to establishing thera a coaling station for the German Navy. This demand has been considered by the Porte. and rumour says that Germany will obtain the harbour which it has demanded.

div.head: GREECE AND EGYPT.
div.p: The protocol of the commercial convention between Greens and Egypt bas been drawn op and the usual exchange of signature has taken place between the Minister of Foreign Affairs and M. Napom, the delegate of the Greek Government.
We understand that the difficulties that at one time impede negotiations have been removed and that a complete settlement of all points at issue may be anticipated.

div.head: MUNICIPAL COMMISSIONS.
div.p: The Superior Council for the Municipal Commissions met on Saturday ander the presidency of Ibrahim Pasha Neghib to consider the budgets of the various Commissions for the current year.

div.head: THE SCHOOL STRIKES.
div.p: The students of the School of Agriculture have returned on being informed by the director of the granting of an amnesty by the Minister of Public Instruction. At 8 a.m. on Saturday all appeared and there is every reason to expect that after their warning they will give no further trouble to the authorities. It is to be hoped that we have how heard the last of these school strikes.

div.head: THE RAILWAY CADRES
div.p: The question of the Cadres of the Egyptian Railway Administration will be finally dealt with by the Ministry of Finance in a few days' time.
The U. S. Army transporta Kilpatrick and McClellar sailed from Suez this forenoon bound to Manila.
The Coast Guard cruiser Nour El Bahr has now entered the drydock here to be overhauled, and H.H.S. Aida is running dispatches between Suez and Akaba temporarily.
H.M. transport Sicilia arrived at Suez yesterday afternoon from Bombay, and entered the Canal the same evening.
The Russian steamer Engineer Ardakoff entered the Canal yesterday evening bound for Alexandria with a tall cargo of rice.

D.S.O., Leicestershire Regiment, to Winifred, daughter of Mr. W. T. Peel, of The Bangalow, Fleming, and Hawley Hill, Blackwater Hants, was solemnized at St. George's Garrison Church, Mustapha, on Saturday, 17th inst. St. Patrick's Day). The church was decorated for the occasion with palms and arum lilies and the service was fully choral, the music and choir being furnished by the band of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers by the kind permission of Col. Bird and the officers of the regiment. The bridegroom was attended by Captain Gordon, Leicestershire Regiment. The bride arrived at 1.45, accompanied by her father. She wore a Liberty picture gown of wbite satin, the corsage draped with Carrickmacross appliqné, the gift of Misa Parsons. Her court train of white silk gauze, lined with chiffon, was carried by ner piece and nephew, Ming Irene and Master Arthur Hogg, and she carried & bouquet of white roses and lilies of the valley aod wore a sapphire and pearl pendant, the gifts of the bridegroom. Hor four bridesmaids were Miss Grace Peel (sister), Miss Paraops, and the Misses Iris and Rhoda Reiss, nieces of the bride. Their dresses were white Oriental satin over mauve silk with mauve sashes and hats of tucked mauve silk trimmed with tuole of a darker shade and pink roses. They carried bouquets of Dijon roses, the two elder bridesmaids wearing gold lockets with the bride's miniature portrait and the younger ones silver moff chains with charms, the gift of the bridegroom. The little page wore & snit of white batin web three-cornered plamed bat. The bride's mother wore a Liberty giwa of soft petania satin with black hat trimmed with feathers and carried & bouquet of white roses. The hymn "O Perfect Love" was. gang, kneeling, st the commencement of the service, which was conducted by the Rev. F. Norman. Lee, chaplain to the forces, assisted by the Rav. Canon Ward, of St Mark's, Alexandria, The bridal party left the church to the strains of Mendelssohn's weddi' g march and prored ed to the Bangalow, where Mrs. W F. Peal held a largely-attended reception.

Captain and Mrs. Knatchboll left during the afternoon for Cairo for & short honeymoon and are leaving Soer tor Colombo on the 12th April. The bride's going-away dress was of silk and she wore & pietore hat of brown propoline straw trimmed with large shaded brown ostrich feathers.

The presents which were very numerous and beautiful included the following as well as some. which, owing to the distance, have not yet arrived. (The most beautiful flowers were sent by Mrs. Crafton, Mrs. Chataway, Mrs. Peroy Carver, Mrr. Moss, Mrs. F. Huselden, Mr. Sandars, and Mrs. Birley):

div.head: ST. PATRICK'S DAY.
ANNUAL IRISH DINNER.
div.p: On Saturday (St. Patrick's Day), the annual Irish dinner was held at Shephe-rd's and proved a thorough success. The table decorations, in which the shamrock 'figured largely, were ornamental at first and useful as the evening wore on, and the band of the 2nd Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers played a series of selections of thoroughly national character though we missed certain airs which were perhaps regarded as "party tapes."

Thirty-five Irisbmen in all were present, Johnson Pacha taking the chair, and a telegram was received early in the evening from the Innis killings in Crete wishing success to the banquet and good fortune to the Irishmen in Cairo. The Toasts of “The King,” "Ireland,” The Services," and “Ourselves” met with a great reception and a number of speeches were made several simultaneously.

Among those present were Johnson Paoba. Dr. Restinge. Capt. Mackenzie, Dr. Norman Capt. Evans, Dr Garner, Messrs. Langley Carren, McLoughlin, Weldon, O'Sullivan, Bewley, Young, Graves, Mackenzie, Rafferty, Duke, Kearney. FitzPatrick, de la Poer French, Brown, Debbs, Plankatt, Loftas, Roth well, Adams, Daffin, McDonnell, Delaney, Parser, Smith and Boxwell.
The thanks of all are due to Johnson Poche and to Mr. Weldon, to whose exertions the success of the banquet were mainly due.

div.head: Anglo-American Stores
div.p: Ramleh Boulevard, Alexandria.
Groceries and Provisions of Best Quality
Just arrived : New Season's Goods.
Goods Guaranteed Fresh.
New Supplies Fortnightly.
27533-12-6 Give us a Trial.

Minieh, Saturday. Minieh yesterday was en fête In the forenoon the annual Horse Show was held at which the judging was done by a Commission including HH Prince Omar Toussoun, Ahmed Bey Bakri and Mr. Littlewood. In the afternoon, thanks to the enterprise and generosity of Omar Bey Soltan, a most successful and enjoyable Skye Meeting was held. Omar Bey has laid sat a pretty mile (ourse on his estate at Damaris, and thanks to his energy and the efforts of the hon. seo., Mohamed Bfi. Naguib, & very good entry was received for the five races of which the programme consisted. Of these, three were won by Fenwick, who had come down to ride, but undoubtedly the event of the afternoon was the race, open to gentlemen riders only, for the bandsome silver cap. presented by Omar Boy Sultan. The trophy was carried off by Mr. Boxwell on Patrick, M. Philippa finishing second. In the other events some excellent racing was seen, and the sportsmanlike manner in which all the local competitors rode augurs well for the success of future meetings. Mr. Haselden is to be congratulated on the successful manner in which he discharged the duties of starter. An excellent tea was provided by Omar Bey Sultan, and the intervals were enlivened by the local band discoursing popular air. The prizes were distributed by H.E. the Mondir, Soliman Bey Osman, and the proceedings closed with three bearty cheers for Omar Bey Sultan, who had provided 08 with such an excellent afternoon's sport. There were at least 5,000 spectators present and in addition to all the local celebrities, we noticed many visitors from Assiout, Beni Suof and the Fayoum. The police arrangements under Mr. Hopkins were excellent.

A most enjoyable garden-party was afterwards held by Mrs. Hopkins ar d Mrs. Noel Haselden at the former's house, during which Mr. Burnand delighted all present with his spirited imitations. In the evening dinner parties were given by Mrs. Hopkins, Mra. Hyeelden and Mr. Bornand.

The following is a list of the winners :MINIA TRIAL PLATE (value P.T. .00) for Araha 3 and 4 years old. Distance 1/2 mile catch weights, 1st, Aly Eff. Shemv's Sahab; 2nd, Abdel Hakeem Mobamed's Maaloom; 3rd, Abdel Bakv's Avenb.
BEDOUIN STAKES (valae P.T. 100n) for all A rabs. Distanda 2 mileg. Catch weights. let, Omar Mibanny's Kobra-hab; 2nd, Ahmed Fff. Fathy's Fayoom; 3-d, Ahmed Mob. Khalifa's Maymore.
DAMARIS STAKES (valos P.T. 500) for horses of all ages, Distance 1 mile. Catch weight, let, Said Bey Azmy's Khartoum; 2nd. Yanis Ef. Taraf- Antar; ?rd Said Alveil Seabeay's Nassib.
MINIA Cup for horses owned and ridden by gentlemen riders. Distance 5 farlonge. Catch weight. over 11st. 71b., for Cap presented by Omar Bey Saltan. 1st, Mr. Boxwell's Patrick; 2nd, M. Phillippa.
CHAMPION STAKES (valae P.T. 500) for winners and seconds in all previous races except Minia Cnp. Distance 1 mile. 18t, Said Bey Azmy's Khartoum ; 2nd, Aly Bff. Sbimy's Sabab; 3rd, Abdel Baky': Ayoub.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: H. H. Prince Ibrahim Pasha Halim left for Bororo hy the Austrian boat on Saturday.
The Prime Minister is giving a dinner to 100 guests at the Savoy on the 26th inst.
H. E. the Governor of Alexandria, accompanied by Hopkinson Bey, paid a visit tbie morning to the Commandant of the French training ship Duguay Trouin.
Baron G. de Renter has arrived at Cairo.

The marriage of Gertrude May, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barker, to Mr. Stanley Jones Gordon, will take place at St. Mark's Church, Alexandria, at 1.30 p. m. on Thursday, 19th April. A reception will afterwards be held at the residence of the bride's parents.

The following parrengørs left for the Nile by the P. S. Nefertari on Friday :- Mr. W. P, &qnire, Mr. and Mrs. J Morrirey, Mr. A. Lerche, Mr. and Mrs. G. W. Engelbardt, Mr. H. Engelhardt, Miss Hunter, Miss Jay, Mr. Carl Crome, Rev. O Hotton Costes, Miss Coates, Miss Hunter, Mr. and Mrs. R. Vischer, Mrs. Le Clercq, Mrs. Le Clercq.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Westcott S.S. Orchis arrived last night from Antwerp, London and Malta with general cargo.
The Ellerman S.S Algation sailed from Malta on Saturday night and is due here on Wednesday morning.

div.head: Isherwood's Cairo Cigarettes.
div.p: The reputation which these Cigarettes have gained in the past, stands unrivalled today, because it is well-known that constant care and attention is devoted to supplying treally first-class Cigarettes only.
Between the Bristish Consulate and Turf Club.

div.head: A.S.O.
div.p: We ara asked by the Clerk of the Course to give notice that the race course will be open for trial gallops on Tuesday morning next, the 20tb inst., from six to ten.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL SPORTING CLUB.
SUCCESSFUL GYMKHANA.
div.p: A most successful Gymkhana was held on the grounds of the Khedivial Sporting Club on Saturday afternoon. A Gymkhana is nearly always a more cheery, though perhaps a less exciting, function than an ordinary race meeting. The events with their variety of elements often have more interest in themselves, and certainly infinitely more amusement, and the presence of the fair sex as competitors on the course helps to keep alert the attention. This season, too, we have bad but few of these informal meetings, and affinity stakes, hattrimming competitions, dak competitions, and the like brought back a flavour of the East and were welcome to many for old association's zake. The attendance was very large and the interest great, as there were but few who had not some friends competing for at least one of the eight events.

Among those present we noticed Lord Edward Ceoil, Sir William Garstin, Sir John and Lady Rogers, Johnson Pacha, Mr. Webb, Mr. Carter Wilson, Lady and Miss Hemming, Cronksbank Pacha and Mrs. Crooksbank Lady and Miss Paul General: Mrs. and Miss Bullock, Capt. and Mrs. Roca Sant. and Mrs. Maclean, Col. Watson and Major and Mrs. Parsons, Capt. & Mrs. Finnegan. Capt. and Mrs. Satow, Mr. and Mrs. Knight, Capt. and Mrs. Smiley, Lady and Miss Lampson, Mrs. and Miss Pennieardie, Mr. Reid, Mr. and Mrs. Scott-Dalgleish, Mrs. and Misses Coles, Mr. Paraviciti, Mr. Robertson, Mrs. Nilav, the Mias Farrar. Mr. and Mrs. Crawford, Major Lawson, Mr. Saunders, Mr. and Mr R E Fisher, Dr. Curling Hayward, Mr. and Mrs. Masson, Mrs. and the Misses York, Mr. Adams, Mr. Kenneth Spiers, 'Mlle. Alla Zekreveky, the Misses Blyth, Mr. and Mrs. P. W. Stout, Mr. and Mrs. Nathan, Dr. Armustrong, Mrs. Trimens. Mr. and Mrs. Cranston, Dr. and Mrs. Amster, the Misses Delanoy, Miss Phillippe, Mr. Wright, Mrs. Rom, Mr and Mrs A. V. Thompson, Miss Maclnnes, Mme and Mlles. Villebois. Mrs. and Miss Whitaker, Mr. McLoughlin, the Misses Lefroy, Miss W. Sheppard, Mr. Collins, Mrs. Back, Miss Gordon Scott, Mr. Manson, Miss Cumberlidge, Mr. and Miss Párnell, Hon. Mrs. Findlay, Mrs. Gordon, Mr. and Miss Allen Joseph, Miss Osborne, Mr. and Mrs. Hatason, Mrs. George Royle, Mr. Mason, Mrs. Molenworth, Mira Wills. Mrs. Stubbs, Mrs. Mackenzie.

The next event was & half-mile race for Arabs that had never raced before in any other than gymkhana races and that had never been trained, catch weights, for which there were 12 entries. All the horses started in a bunch and there was but little to choose among them until the curve was reached, when Mr. Miller got well ahead in the straight. However, Capt. Hills, riding Major Palmer's horse, drew up and finally gained the lead and won in splendid style, Mr. Miller coming in second and Mr. Loftus a fairly good third.

The Affinity Stakes, in which a gentleman and & lady holding a ribbon between them galloped 200 yards round & post and returned to winning post without letting go the ribbon, was ron in two beats, the first two of each competing in the final. In the first beat Mr. Dalby and Mrs. Bayley ran home first, closely followed by Mr. Langley and Mrs. Molesworth, and in the second heat Capt. Rome and Mrs. Blyth ran in well in advance of the rest of the field. The final resulted in a close race between Mr. Dalby and Mrs. Mackenzie and Captain and Mrs. Rome, the former pair winning narrowly.

In the hat-trimming competition there was much amusement. In not a few cases the trimming refused to stop on the bat and some of the riders lost their hats altogether. Mr. R. E. Fischer was distinctly unfortunate in losing his horse, which got away while the bats were being trimmed and was caught with difficulty. The winner was Lieut. Mellor, with Mr. Gordop as bi- milliner, and the ropner op Mr. Mason, who was partnered by Mrs. Stobbs.

Considerable excitement was caused by the dak race, in which competitors had to drive at the trot for about ¼ mile, unharness and saddle the same pony, and ride roand a post: 200 yards away, returning to winning post. Several of the horses were most restive and difficult to unharness. One broke through the railings, carrying the dogcart which he was drawing with him, and then turned it on its side, while another broke away from its trap and was not caught for some time. Mr. Mason came in first unchallenged and Mr. Langley gained second place. In the Ladies' Sourry, which consisted of a two furlongs pony race the most notable feature was the splendid riding of Miss Blyth, who came in an easy winner, though Miss Farcar also rode well and deserved the award of second place as she led the rest of the field by several lengths.

Mr. Dalby was unfortunate in not winning the Housekeeping Stakes, in which an addition arm was entrusted to ladies, as he came in first, bint the judges were unable to accept Mrs. Beyley's Addition, and the prize was therefore awarded to Mr. Akers Douglas, who came in second with a sum correctly added up by Mrs. Satow.

In the final event a lady and gentleman had to ride together, the former tilting a ring and the latter taking a peg with a sword. The award was given on the best of rounds and Mr. Protheroe-Smith and Mrs. Rome proved the winners, the former taking the peg at both rounds, and the latter carrying the ring away at the second attempt. Mr. Goodchild and Mrs. Mackenzie were also both successful at the first trial bnt in the recond round Mr. Goodchild missed the peg, though his partner again carried off the ring.
MESSRS. COVEN LACLOCHE Jewellers, beg to inform their customers that their Cairo premises will be closed for the summer season from March 31 to November 15.
